facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 114 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 114 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 21, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 21, 1954, of the Calcutta High Court in Reference No. 6 of 1954, under Section 307 of the Criminal Procedure Code made by the

facts.text: Calcutta High Court judgment in Reference No. 6 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: High Court in Reference No. 6 of 1954, under Section 307 of the Criminal Procedure Code made by the Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas at Alipore on the June 7, 1954,

facts.text: Reference under Section 307 CrPC made by Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas at Alipore on June 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Additional Sessions Judge, 24 Parganas at Alipore on the June 7, 1954, in Sessions Trial No. 2 of May, 1954. C. Isaacs, and S. N. Mukherjee, for the appellants. C. Mitra, D. N.

facts.text: Sessions Trial No. 2 of May, 1954 before Additional Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: 1954, in Sessions Trial No. 2 of May, 1954. C. Isaacs, and S. N. Mukherjee, for the appellants. C. Mitra, D. N. Mukherjee and P. K. Bose, for the respondent. 1957. November 19.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: IMAM J.-In this appeal by special leave the substantial question for consideration is whether the reference

facts.text: Eight accused on trial in Court of Session charged under ss. 147 and 304/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: There were eight accused on trial in the Court of Session all of whom were charged under ss. 147 and 304/149 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Accused No. 1 Sashi Mohan Debnath, No. 2 Rajendra Debnath, No. 3 Manindra Debnath, No. 6 Rohini Kumar Debnath further charged under s. 201 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Four of them, namely, accused No. 1, Sashi Mohan Debnath, accused No. 2, Rajendra Debnath, accused No. 3, Manindra Debnath and accused No. 6, Rohini Kumar Debnath were further charged under s. 201, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Trial Judge delivered charge to jury favourable to accused.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge delivered a charge to the jury which was favourable to the accused.

facts.text: Jury returned unanimous verdict of not guilty under s. 304/149 IPC, accepted by Judge, all accused acquitted of this offence.

anchor.surface_text: The jury returned a unanimous verdict of not guilty under s. 304/149 of the Indian Penal Code, which the learned Judge accepted. He, accordingly, acquitted all the accused charged with this offence.

facts.text: Jury returned unanimous verdict of guilty under ss. 147 and 201 IPC against charged accused.

anchor.surface_text: The jury, however, with respect to charges under ss. 147 and 201 of the Indian Penal Code returned a unanimous verdict of guilty against the accused charged with these offences.

facts.text: Trial Judge disagreed with jury verdict on ss. 147 and 201, made reference under s. 307 CrPC to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge disagreed with this verdict and made a reference under s. 307 of the Code to the High Court, being of the opinion that the accused were not guilty of these offences.

facts.text: High Court accepted reference in part, convicted Sashi Mohan Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudbanshu Kumar Debnath, Dinesh Chandra Debnath and Bonomali Das under s. 147 IPC to 1 year RI.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the reference in part and in agreement with the jurys verdict of guilty under ss. 147 and 201 of the Indian Penal Code convicted the accused Sashi Mohan Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudbanshu Kumar Debnath, Dinesh Chandra Debnath and Bonomali Das under s. 147 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced each of them to undergo one years rigorous imprisonment

facts.text: High Court convicted Sashi Mohan Debnath and Rajendra Debnath under s. 201 IPC to 3 years RI, sentences to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: and the accused Sashi Mohan Debnath and Rajendra Debnath under s. 201 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced each of them to undergo rigorous imprisonment for three years. The sentences with respect to the accused Sashi Mohan Debnath and Rajendra Debnath were ordered to run concurrently.

facts.text: High Court acquitted Manindra Debnath, Gouranga Debnath under s.147, Manindra and Rohini under s.201.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did not accept the verdict of the jury with respect to the accused Manindra Debnath and Gouranga Debnath under s. 147 of the Indian Penal Code and under s. 201 against Manindra Debnath and Rohini Kumar Debnath and acquitted them.

facts.text: Present appeal by accused Sashi Mohan Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudhanshu Kumar Debnath and Bonomali Das.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is by the accused Sashi Mohan, Debnath, Rajendra Debnath, Sudhanshu Kumar Debnath and Bonomali Das.

facts.text: Appeal hearing on September 12, 1956, necessary to issue notices to accused No.3 Manindra, No.6 Rohini, No.8 Gouranga.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal came on for hearing on September 12, 1956, it was found necessary by this Court to have the appeal heard in the presence of the accused No. 3, Manindra Debnath, accused No. 6, Rohini Kumar Debnath and accused No. 8, Gouranga Debnath.

facts.text: Notices issued and served on Manindra Debnath and Gouranga Debnath; Rohini could not be traced.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, notices were issued to these accused and they were served upon Manindra Debnath and Gouranga Debnath. So far as Rohini Kumar Debnath was concerned, it was reported that he could not be traced and none could say where he had gone after selling all his properties and that no relative of his could be found.

facts.text: None of the three accused entered appearances in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: None of these three accused have entered appearances in this Court.

facts.text: Occurrence took place on October 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence took place on October 21, 1953.

facts.text: Letter of reference dated June 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the letter of reference is dated June 7, 1954, that is, more than three years ago.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court judgment, holds reference under s.307 incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on November 19, 1957 by IMAM J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. November 19. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by IMAM J.-

facts.text: High Court should have rejected incompetent reference and remitted to Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court should have rejected the reference as incompetent and remitted the case to the Additional Sessions Judge for disposal according to law.

facts.text: Judge who made reference has retired, successor may not deal with case.

anchor.surface_text: particularly as we are informed that the Judge who made the reference to the High Court has retired from service and it is doubtful whether, in law, his successor can at all deal with the case.

issues.text: whether the reference made to the Calcutta High Court by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur under s. 307 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was competent and, if not, whether the High Court acted with jurisdiction in convicting or acquitting any of the accused who were tried by the Additional sessions Judge and a jury

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave the substantial question for consideration is whether the reference made to the Calcutta High Court by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur under s. 307 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was competent and, if

issues.text: whether the reference made under s. 307 of the Code by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur was competent

anchor.surface_text: In order to determine whether the reference made under s. 307 of the Code by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur was competent, it is necessary to examine the provisions of that section and consider some of the decisions of the High Courts in India in this connection.

issues.text: the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it

anchor.surface_text: If, however, he disagrees and is clearly of the opinion that it was necessary for the ends of justice to submit the case to the High Court he must submit the case accordingly. In our opinion, the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it.

issues.text: whether the action of the Judge in recording a judgment is a mere irregularity

anchor.surface_text: This prohibition is mandatory and a Judge, who records a judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried, contravenes the provisions of s. 307 (2) We cannot accept the submission of the learned Counsel for the appellants that the action of the Judge in recording a judgment is a mere irregularity.

issues.text: whether a competent reference under s. 307 is a condition precedent to the exercise of power by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: But before the High Court could exercise the powers conferred on it under s. 307 (3) it was necessary that the reference under s. 307 should have been according to law. This was, in our opinion, a condition precedent to the exercise of such power by the High Court.

issues.text: what consequential order should be passed by this Court as the result of our conclusion that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent and the appeal succeeding
issues.answer: set aside High Court judgment; no remand due to lapse of time

arguments.claim: the action of the Judge in recording a judgment is a mere irregularity

anchor.surface_text: This prohibition is mandatory and a Judge, who records a judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried, contravenes the provisions of s. 307 (2) We cannot accept the submission of the learned Counsel for the appellants that the action of the Judge in recording a judgment is a mere irregularity.

arguments.court_reasoning: Prohibition is mandatory and recording judgment contravenes s.307(2), making it illegal

arguments.claim: the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it

anchor.surface_text: If, however, he disagrees and is clearly of the opinion that it was necessary for the ends of justice to submit the case to the High Court he must submit the case accordingly. In our opinion, the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it.

arguments.claim: provisions of ss. 306 and 307 when read together require submission of the whole case

anchor.surface_text: This appears to us to be clearly the effect of the provisions of ss. 306 and 307 when read together. Section 307 (2) specifically prohibits the Judge...

arguments.claim: prohibition in s.307(2) is mandatory; recording judgment contravenes it and is illegal

anchor.surface_text: Section 307 (2) specifically prohibits the Judge, when be considers it necessary to submit the case by way of reference to the High Court, from recording any judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried. This prohibition is mandatory

arguments.claim: competent reference under s.307 is a condition precedent to High Court exercising powers under s.307(3)

anchor.surface_text: But before the High Court could exercise the powers conferred on it under s. 307 (3) it was necessary that the reference under s. 307 should have been according to law. This was, in our opinion, a condition precedent to the exercise of such power by the High Court.

arguments.claim: amendments to s.307 in 1923 and 1955 indicate that whole case must be referred

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the amendments to s. 307 of the Code made in 1923 and 1955 lend further support to the view that it is the whole case which must be referred and not a part of it

arguments.claim: view of Patna High Court in Hazari Lal case correct: reference must be whole case

anchor.surface_text: The Patna High Court in Hazari Lal-s case expressed the opinion that having regard to the provisions of s. 307 a reference made thereunder must be of the whole case against the accused and not a part of it.

arguments.court_reasoning: in accordance with provisions of s.307

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor v. Jagmohan , while the learned Judges held that the reference to the High Court only of a part of the case was irregular, the High Court could consider not Only the part of the case referred to it, but the whole case. We are unable to accept this view.

arguments.claim: in Emperor v. Ananda Charan Ray, Calcutta HC effectively held reference incompetent

anchor.surface_text: This decision, in substance, takes the same view as that expressed by the Patna High Court in the cases of Hazari Lal and Ramjanam Tewari.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: framed under secs. 406 and 477A, Indian Penal Cod

arguments.court_reasoning: takes same view as Patna HC

arguments.claim: reference incompetent, High Court should have rejected it and remitted to Sessions Judge

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent. ... The High Court should have rejected the reference as incompetent and remitted the case to the Additional Sessions Judge

arguments.claim: due to lapse of time and retirement of judge, no remand to Sessions Judge
judge must disagree on all charges to refer; cannot accept on some and refer others

anchor.surface_text: In order to determine whether the reference made under s. 307 of the Code by the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur was competent, it is necessary to examine the provisions of that section... When the jury have given their verdict in the case, then the Judge has to consider whether he agrees with it and, if he does, then he must give judgment accordingly.

holdings.text: the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it

anchor.surface_text: If, however, he disagrees and is clearly of the opinion that it was necessary for the ends of justice to submit the case to the High Court he must submit the case accordingly. In our opinion, the case to be submitted to the High Court is the whole case against the accused and not a part of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of ss. 306 and 307 read harmoniously requires submission of entire case when judge disagrees with jury verdict

holdings.text: This prohibition is mandatory and a Judge, who records a judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried, contravenes the provisions of s. 307 (2)

anchor.surface_text: This prohibition is mandatory and a Judge, who records a judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried, contravenes the provisions of s. 307 (2) We cannot accept the submission of the learned Counsel for the appellants that the action of the Judge in recording a judgment is a mere irregularity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.307(2) expressly prohibits recording judgment when submitting reference; violation renders action illegal, not mere irregularity

holdings.text: a competent reference under s. 307 is a condition precedent to the exercise of power by the High Court under s.307(3)

anchor.surface_text: But before the High Court could exercise the powers conferred on it under s. 307 (3) it was necessary that the reference under s. 307 should have been according to law. This was, in our opinion, a condition precedent to the exercise of such power by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court powers under s.307(3) apply only to 'the case so submitted'; incompetent reference lacks foundation for jurisdiction

holdings.text: the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judge accepted jury on s.304/149, acquitted, recorded judgment, then referred only on s.147/201; violates mandatory whole-case requirement

holdings.text: The High Court should have rejected the reference as incompetent and remitted the case to the Additional Sessions Judge for disposal according to law

anchor.surface_text: The High Court should have rejected the reference as incompetent and remitted the case to the Additional Sessions Judge for disposal according to law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Incompetent reference deprives High Court of power; proper course is rejection and remand to sessions judge

holdings.text: After such lapse of time we will not order that the case be returned to the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge of Alipur for disposal according to law
holdings.reasoning_summary: Over 3 years since reference, occurrence in 1953, referring judge retired; successor may lack authority; avoids complications

holdings.text: the view taken by the Patna High Court was correct and in accordance with the provisions of s. 307

anchor.surface_text: The Patna High Court in Hazari Lal-s case expressed the opinion that having regard to the provisions of s. 307 a reference made thereunder must be of the whole case against the accused and not a part of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Patna HC in Hazari Lal and Ramjanam Tewari correctly held reference must be whole case

holdings.text: We are unable to accept this view [Emperor v. Jagmohan]

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor v. Jagmohan , while the learned Judges held that the reference to the High Court only of a part of the case was irregular, the High Court could consider not Only the part of the case referred to it, but the whole case. We are unable to accept this view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allahabad HC erred; partial reference incompetent, High Court cannot exercise s.307(3) powers

anchor.surface_text: The Patna High Court in Hazari Lal-s case  1  expressed the opinion that having regard to the provisions of s. 307 a reference made thereunder must be of the whole case against the accused and number a part of it. If only a part of it is referred then the reference made under s. 307 is incompetent. That High Court reaffirmed the view taken in Hazari Lals case in the case of Ramjanam Tewari 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: having regard to the provisions of s. 307 a reference made thereunder must be of the whole case against the accused and not a part of it. If only a part of it is referred then the reference made under s. 307 is incompetent

anchor.surface_text: That High Court reaffirmed the view taken in Hazari Lals case in the case of Ramjanam Tewari 2 . This was the view also taken by the three Judges of the Calcutta High Court in the case of The Emperor v. Bishnu Chandra Das 3 , two of whom, however, in rejecting the reference directed that the accused be acquitted.

precedents.cited_proposition: reaffirmed that a reference under s. 307 must be of the whole case against the accused and not a part of it

precedents.citation: The Emperor v. Bishnu Chandra Das 1933 37 C. W. N. 1180

anchor.surface_text: This was the view also taken by the three Judges of the Calcutta High Court in the case of The Emperor v. Bishnu Chandra Das 3 , two of whom, however, in rejecting the reference directed that the accused be acquitted. The third Judge, Mr. Justice McNair, however, confined himself to the observation that the Sessions Judge had disabled himself from making a valid reference under s. 307 of the Code by accepting the verdict of the jury against the accused on some of the charges.

precedents.case_name: The Emperor v. Bishnu Chandra Das
precedents.cited_proposition: a reference under s. 307 must be of the whole case; Sessions Judge disabled from valid reference by accepting verdict on some charges

precedents.citation: King Emperor v. Ananda Charan Ray 1916 21 C.W.N. 435, 437

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, submitted on behalf of the appellants that in view of certain decisions of the Calcutta High Court and the Allahabad High Court, when a reference had in fact been made, it was open to the High Court to deal with it and record a judgment. Reference was made to the case of King Emperor v. Ananda Charan Ray  4 .

precedents.case_name: King Emperor v. Ananda Charan Ray
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court can consider evidence and deal with partial reference under s. 307

precedents.citation: Emperor v. Nawal Behari 1930 I.L.R. All. 881

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Emperor v. Nawal Behari 1 , the learned Judges of the Allahabad High Court held that when a Sessions Judge refers a case under s. 307 of the Code, he must refer the whole case against the particular accused and not merely those charges on which there happens to be a finding by the jury with which lie disagrees.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sessions Judge must refer the whole case under s. 307, not merely charges disagreed with

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Emperor v. Jagmohan 1 , while the learned Judges held that the reference to the High Court only of a part of the case was irregular, the High Court could consider not only the part of the case referred to it, but the whole case. We are unable to accept this view.

precedents.cited_proposition: reference of only part of case under s. 307 is irregular but High Court can consider the whole case

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor v. Muktar 2 the learned Judges were of the opinion that the reference was not in order when the trial Judge recorded a finding on some charges in respect of the very accused whose cases so far as other charges were concerned were referred, but the defect was not necessarily fatal to the reference and the High Court might entertain the same.

precedents.cited_proposition: defect in reference under s. 307 from recording finding on some charges not necessarily fatal; High Court may entertain

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed, High Court judgment set aside as reference under s.307 CrPC was incompetent, no remand to Sessions Judge due to lapse of time and retirement of the trial judge.
directions: Set aside the judgment of the High Court
Held the reference under s.307 incompetent
Declined to remit the case back to Additional Sessions Judge for disposal

h2 holds that recording judgment contravenes the mandatory prohibition, addressing whether it is a mere irregularity

anchor.surface_text: This prohibition is mandatory and a Judge, who records a judgment of acquittal or of conviction on any of the charges on which the accused had been tried, contravenes the provisions of s. 307 (2) We cannot accept the submission of the learned Counsel for the appellants that the action of the Judge in recording a judgment is a mere irregularity.
We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent.

But before the High Court could exercise the powers conferred on it under s. 307 (3) it was necessary that the reference under s. 307 should have been according to law. This was, in our opinion, a condition precedent to the exercise of such power by the High Court.
We, accordingly, allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and hold that the reference under s. 307 to the High Court was incompetent.
